role: Design, prototype, and maintain a transparent, verifiable, publicly-auditable voting system for the digital age.
summary: Voting Lab is an open, transparent research and design environment for building a next-generation voting system. It prioritizes verifiability, auditability, accessibility, security, and public trust. This is where we experiment with new prototypes, cross-validate civic models, and design systems that could serve as the backbone of future democracies — local, national, or digital.

pillars.purpose: Give the people a voting system they can see, understand, audit, and trust — without needing to trust any private institution.
pillars.methods: UI prototyping, cryptographic verification models, live data visualizations, threat modeling, mock elections, audit trails, decentralized identity frameworks, and cross-state compatibility testing.
pillars.outputs: Working prototypes, UX flows, vote integrity proofs, system diagrams, election simulations, security whitepapers, and integration guides for real jurisdictions.

projects.title: Live Election Sandbox
projects.summary: A real-time, publicly viewable election simulation environment where users can cast mock ballots. Features verifiable tallies, open audit logs, and cryptographic integrity proofs.

projects.title: Decentralized Voter Identity Framework
projects.summary: Design of a secure, privacy-preserving identity system using decentralized identifiers (DIDs) or zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). Ensures eligibility without compromising anonymity.

projects.title: Ballot Audit Chain
projects.summary: A tamper-proof ledger for storing cryptographic ballot commitments and public audit trails. Every citizen can verify the integrity of their own vote — without revealing how they voted.

projects.title: U.S. Election Integration Suite
projects.summary: A modular integration layer for interfacing with real U.S. election data sources (registrar data, turnout, precinct maps, ballot templates). Includes compliance notes for state-by-state differences.
